title.narrative: 3.1.2: EMERGENCY EDUCATION

description.narrative: By 2012, 50% of boys and girls of primary school age in situations of conflict have access to education., which contributes to Education In Emergencies, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Skills Development. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2016, 80% of school aged children, especially girls and the most vulnerable, benefit from access to basic education.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
HSS - Risk informed programming including climate resilience disaster and conflict
Provision of (formal and non-formal) multiple-levels or alternative pathways of education (including in temporary learning spaces)
Provision of skills development for multiple age groups (including in temporary learning spaces)
Public health emergencies, including disease outbreaks
Relief co-ordination, protection and support services
System strengthening - risk informed programming, including climate, resilience, disaster, conflict, and emergency preparedness

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2012, 50% of boys and girls of primary school age in situations of conflict have access to education.

description.narrative: Coordination and humanitarian response of the education sector are ensured through Cluster meetings which allowed for the identification of needs and the delivery of a coordinated response. UNICEF through implementing partners ensured that over 57,600 children in areas affected by the crisis had access to quality education | Status:On-track | As-of Date:17/01/2018
